title: Health Supplements | helping you recover post-workout
text: Learn more about health supplements » Every new year you see a rush of faddy new exercise regimes, whether it’s Clubbercise, Piloxing or Aerial Yoga – I mean, most people don’t want to go up the London Eye, let alone be suspended from a ceiling. Military-style obstacle courses are also very on-trend, while everybody loves Bikram (Hot) Yoga. But just because you’re sweating doesn’t mean you’re burning extra calories. Everybody should try to do some exercise every day, even if it just walking to work or using the stairs. Pace and intensity are always key to getting fitter Fitness used to be more about gym memberships: big time and financial commitments. Today it’s short, sharp 15-minute workouts that you can do at home without equipment. It’s old-school calisthenics. By and large, if you follow this you will get results. Everybody should try to do some gentle exercise every day, even if it just walking to work or using the stairs. Pace and intensity are always key to getting fitter though. The problem is that most of us do not have a well-balanced diet . Even my healthiest clients probably don’t ingest anywhere near the recommended daily allowance of vitamins. Vitamins C and E have good antioxidant properties that help with the stress of tough training sessions and can help ward off infection. L-Glutamine is an amino acid that many find helps recovery after a workout. I take a Solgar Vitamin B-Complex for the nervous system and Solgar Vitamin C for tissue repair and immune function every day.
